BOGUS INSURANCE COMPANIES


    3. Mr Ong Chang Sam asked the Minister for Finance what progress has been made in the action taken against bogus insurance companies since 9th April. 1963.

    The Minister for Health and Law (Mr K. M. Byrne) (for the Minister for Finance): Mr Speaker. Sir, the Member for Choa Chu Kang will recall that in the last sitting of the Legislative Assembly in April, he was informed that the process of liquidating bogus insurance companies was in the hands of liquidators appointed by the High Court of Singapore in respect of three insurance companies incorporated in the State, and by the High Court of Malaya in respect of the other 13 insurance companies incorporated in the Federation.

    The liquidators of most of these companies are still processing, summarising and sorting out tens of thousands of claims from all over Malaya and Singapore, as well as realising the assets of

Column: 5

companies where available. The liquidators of two insurance companies - one from Singapore and the other from Malaya - however, have already begun paying out claims to policy holders, and payments are now almost completed. These payments are practically in full satisfaction of claims by policy holders. The process to make payments of claims to policy holders for another two companies - again one from Singapore and the other from the Federation - is reaching its final stages and claimants will receive their payments within the next three months.

    The liquidators for the Singapore company reported that all claims from policy holders can be met in full. The remaining one Singapore insurance company under liquidation proved to be insolvent and some legal action is still necessary before any payment can be made.

    As for the other bogus insurance companies incorporated in Malaya, it is not known how long the liquidators will take before any payment to policy holders can be made. However, as stated before, many of these companies were in a poor financial position and it would be optimistic for any policy holder to expect more than a small fraction of his claims to be honoured.

FLOATATION OF GOVERNMENT LOANS SINCE 3RD JUNE, 1959


    4. Mr Ong Chang Sam asked the Minister for Finance since 3rd June, 1959 (i) how many loans have so far been floated by the Government; (ii) what is the amount for each loan; and (iii) what has been done with them.

    Mr Byrne (for the Minister for Finance): Sir, since 3rd June, 1959, five loans have been floated by the Government, one for each year from 1959 to1963.

    The total amount of loan in respect of the five loans is $247,514,000. The breakdown of this figure is as follows:

Column: 6



    In 1959, $40 million was floated under the Development Loan (Local) Ordinance, 1959 (No. 50 of 1959).

    In 1960, $30 million under the same Ordinance.

    In 1961, $50 million was floated under the Development Loan Ordinance, 1961 (No. 7 of 1961).

    In 1962, $60 million under that Ordinance, and in 1963, $67,514,000 under the same Ordinance.

NATIONAL REFERENDUM
(Applications for restoration of names to 1962 Registers of Electors)


    7. Mr Ong Chang Sam asked the Minister for Home Affairs (a) how many voters did not vote in the National Referendum held on 1st September,

1962; (b) how many of them applied for their names to be restored to the 1962 Registers of Electors; (c) how many have had their names restored in the 1962 Registers of Electors; and (d) how many applications were rejected and why.

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, 53,581 persons did not vote at the National Referendum.

    7,418 applied to have their names restored to the 1962 Register of Electors.

    6,467 have had their names restored to the 1962 Register of Electors.

INTERNATIONAL RED CROSS
(Report on conditions of Singapore detainees)


    10. Mr David Marshall asked the Minister for Home Affairs whether he

Column: 10

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, a report has been received from the Vice-President of the International Red Cross. A reply has been sent to the Vice-President thanking him for the report and informing him that steps have been taken to improve the conditions of detainees which are now better, and, therefore, the Government does not consider it necessary to publish this private report.

    Mr David Marshall: Will the Minister reconsider the question particularly in the light of the inaccurate appellation that it is a "private" report? The International Red Cross is a public organisation. It was invited here for a public purpose at the request of public personalities.

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, the main objection, as far as we gather from the report, is that the detainees were confined individually in their cells in Outram Prison. No detainee is being confined individually in his cell at Outram Prison now. So there is no need to publish the report.

    Mr David Marshall: Mr Speaker, Sir, thank you for your indulgence. Would the Minister consider that if, in fact, everything now is rosy in the garden there is no real reason why the report and its recommendations should be prevented from being known by the citizens of this country. What is there the Government is afraid or ashamed of?

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, there is nothing to be ashamed of. Most of the recommendations have already been carried out.

    17. Mr David Marshall asked the Minister for National Development whether he will consider instituting a sociological enquiry into the effects on persons re-housed in units erected by the Singapore Improvement Trust and the Housing and Development Board in the past ten years.
